awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Cosmic Ray Neutron Sensing for Soil Water Measurements at Irrigation Decision Resolution
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is a touchless, crop agnostic, automatic, always on, non-drifting, and cost-effective way of measuring soil moisture in large fields with data specific to each irrigation zone. The goal is to enable irrigators in water-scarce environments to maximize yields given the water available, and to mitigate the impacts of drought and aquifer reduction by enabling irrigators to calibrate their systems to the precise needs of the plants.  The impact of this system is to maximize productivity of irrigation water, reducing waste and costs for crop growers and other irrigators. The commercialization of this product will provide the data needed for precision irrigation to respond to daily ground water needs, broadly reducing water consumption in agriculture and other markets. This technology translates a known methodology for soil moisture monitoring used by researchers and academics into a tool that delivers actionable data to end users that steward the world’s water resources. 


The goal of the proposed research and development is to verify that data from an arrayed set of smaller Cosmic Ray Neutron Sensing (CRNS) systems, ingested into an interpolation algorithm, can provide a soil moisture heat map with resolution at the level of each irrigation point for water measurements in the field. This project will remove the main technical risks associated with applying the CRNS methodology to a sub-field measurement scale, providing actionable data through granular moisture analysis. This data will be compared with a similar heat map generated by a multi hour, high labor assay using a manual probing system. This comparison seeks to support automated, precision irrigation systems to minimize water usage and correct for overwatering. The main technical hurdles that will be addressed include: the data collection from an array of smaller-form-factor CRNS systems that are placed on the field at the spacing of the desired measurement resolution; integration of neutron count data over the large temporal scales that are necessary to overcome the noise associated with the less efficient detectors; and the ability to provide the necessary temporally-changing information that is relevant to the irrigation manager.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Across the American West, water managers are under great pressure to reduce the amount of water used to irrigate of everything from farm fields to golf fairways. They struggle because they lack the core data they need: how much water is in the ground, and thus how much should they put down. This problem arises because the spatial resolution of available methods of soil moisture measurement do not align with the scale of irrigation decisions: a center pivot covers a large field with multiple zones and a sprinkler head throws water ~20 meters, but prevailing soil moisture monitoring technologies have challenges to measure at this scale. Point probes measure water in cubic centimeters of dirt, and due to heterogeneities of soil moisture, struggle to scale to the desired measurement resolution even with multiple sensor readings. Satellites, on the other hand, measure soil moisture over a square kilometer. Neither technology can extrapolate to the irrigation pixel, and thus provide meaningful, actionable data to the grower.

Cosmic Ray Neutron Sensing (CRNS) is a method that determines the water content of soil through the inverse correlation of ground-level measurements of low-energy neutrons and the percentage of water in the ground. The benefit of this water measuring method is that it delivers a non-drifting, soil-type agnostic, continuous and autonomous measurement of average soil moisture within the 160 m radius area around a neutron sensor.

The goal of this project was to prove the capability of an innovative framework of multiple smaller CRNS sensors, with heavily overlapping 160 m readout regions (down to 20 m between sensors), to provide the same non-drifting, continuous, soil-type agnostic, autonomous measurement as traditional sensors, but with a variable spatial resolution smaller than the 160 m natural measurement region. The concept investigates resolution down to 10 m, targeting the spacing of irrigation heads, to provide actionable resolution of water information across field-sized areas.

The major activity was to deploy a network of 60 small detectors within 30 locations (two detectors per node for redundancy and detector variance observations) within an irrigated field and collect multiple months of background data (Figure 1). The follow-on task was to run an experiment where the irrigation is purposefully manipulated to observe the response of the sensor network. After collecting this data, we applied advanced optimization interpolation algorithms to generate heatmaps that correlate with the soil moisture content at the desired spatial resolution.

Figure 2 shows the results: heatmaps calculated using the optimized interpolation algorithms using data from the irrigation manipulation experiment. The dotted black line through the middle of the plot denotes the barrier between the dry/wet, then wet/dry portions of the irrigation manipulation experiment. Plot A shows the end of the dry (left of dotted line) / wet (right of dotted line) irrigation schedule, and Plot B shows two days after the switch to wet (left of dotted line) / dry (right of dotted line) irrigation schedule. This example shows the method’s ability to view changes in volumetric water content (VWC) over 48-hour timeframes at the resolution of the spacing of the sensor nodes. 

Additionally, the resulting heatmaps show the same trends in excess water and drying patterns that can be seen with a hand-held, manual soil moisture measuring tool currently used at the golf course to inform irrigation decisions, shown in Figure 3. 

During the Phase I period of performance, we accomplished both major goals of the project: 

  • Demonstrated that small neutron detectors—with a significantly reduced efficiency when compared to common CRNS sensors (allowing them to install underground, low-cost, and deployed in a large array)—can overcome the noise associated with the low detection efficiency of each system and give meaningful water measurements.
  • Demonstrated that at-ground level neutron detectors with highly overlapped measurement footprints (node to node distance of about 20 m) can obtain a resolution of soil moisture well within the integrated 160 m radius, to a resolution that is half of the distance between each detector node (10 m).

The Phase I results set the stage for a larger-scale and longer-duration Phase II experiment, which will target specific crops and irrigation systems. These results de-risk the next stage, as the findings establish the fundamental performance of the innovation. Follow-on work will target demonstrating the applicability of the soil moisture data to real-world agriculture environments, as well as the integration value into irrigation systems. The next stage will prioritize putting the technology in the hands of end-users and irrigation system developers, testing the data's actionability for real-time watering decisions.
